responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Cleartext Storage of LDAP Password
    analysis: |
      The LDAP password is stored in plain text in the `LDAPSecurityRealmTest.yml` file.
      An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this password.
    cwe: CWE-312
    function_names:
      - configure_securityRealm
    filenames:
      - src/test/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/LDAPSecurityRealmTest.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Cleartext Storage of GitHub Client Secret
    analysis: |
      The GitHub OAuth plugin Client Secret is stored in plain text in the `GithubOAuth.yml` file.
      An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this secret.
    cwe: CWE-312
    function_names:
      - testSampleVersionForOAuth
    filenames:
      - src/test/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/GithubOAuthTest.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Cleartext Storage of Active Directory Password
    analysis: |
      The Active Directory bind password is stored in plain text in the `ActiveDirectoryTest.yml` file.
      An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this password.
    cwe: CWE-312
    function_names:
      - configure_active_directory
    filenames:
      - src/test/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/ActiveDirectoryTest.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Cleartext Storage of System Credentials
    analysis: |
      Multiple system credentials are stored in plain text in the `SystemCredentialsTest.yml` file, including an SSH private key, an SSH key password, and a sudo password.
      An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read these credentials.
    cwe: CWE-312
    function_names:
      - configure_system_credentials
    filenames:
      - src/test/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/SystemCredentialsTest.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Jenkins Configuration Stored in Plain Text
    analysis: |
      Jenkins configuration can be set by passing a URL or file path.
      If an attacker can control the contents of this location, they can control the Jenkins configuration.
      While secrets can be fetched from Docker secrets or a Hashicorp Vault, the path to these secrets
      are still stored in the configuration file.
    cwe: CWE-20
    function_names:
      - configure
      - _configureWithURI
      - _configureWithPaths
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/ConfigurationAsCode.java
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Environment Variables as Secret Source
    analysis: |
      While Docker secrets and Hashicorp Vault can be used to provide secrets to the Jenkins configuration, environment variables can also be used.
      An attacker with control over environment variables could set sensitive values, such as passwords and API tokens.
    cwe: CWE-20
    function_names:
      - reveal
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/casc/EnvSecretSource.java
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Cleartext Storage of LDAP Password
leads.analysis:
The LDAP password is stored in plain text in the LDAPSecurityRealmTest.yml file.
An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this password.

leads.headline: Cleartext Storage of GitHub Client Secret
leads.analysis:
The GitHub OAuth plugin Client Secret is stored in plain text in the GithubOAuth.yml file.
An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this secret.

leads.headline: Cleartext Storage of Active Directory Password
leads.analysis:
The Active Directory bind password is stored in plain text in the ActiveDirectoryTest.yml file.
An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read this password.

leads.headline: Cleartext Storage of System Credentials
leads.analysis:
Multiple system credentials are stored in plain text in the SystemCredentialsTest.yml file, including an SSH private key, an SSH key password, and a sudo password.
An attacker with access to the Jenkins controller file system could read these credentials.

leads.headline: Jenkins Configuration Stored in Plain Text
leads.analysis:
Jenkins configuration can be set by passing a URL or file path.
If an attacker can control the contents of this location, they can control the Jenkins configuration.
While secrets can be fetched from Docker secrets or a Hashicorp Vault, the path to these secrets
are still stored in the configuration file.

leads.headline: Environment Variables as Secret Source
leads.analysis:
While Docker secrets and Hashicorp Vault can be used to provide secrets to the Jenkins configuration, environment variables can also be used.
An attacker with control over environment variables could set sensitive values, such as passwords and API tokens.
